Award.AwardTitle: Hazards SEES Type 1: Predicting Landslide Runout and Granular Flow Hazard: Enhanced-g Centrifuge Experiments, Contact Dynamics Model Development and Theoretical Study

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The broad goal of this project is to address the unpredictability of landslides and debris flows and to boost societal resilience and sustainability in the face of growing landslide hazard and risk across the world. Landslides and debris flows are frequent agents of natural disaster and they pose a particular challenge because their timing, location, size and impact on infrastructure and people are notoriously hard to predict. Such unpredictability undermines society's ability to make accurate risk assessments, to frame safe design principles or to enforce sound engineering codes. This project is being tackled by an interdisciplinary team of computer scientists, engineers and geoscientists working together on laboratory experiments and numerical simulations. The research is framed around enhanced-g experiments conducted on a state-of-the-art geotechnical centrifuge.

These experiments are designed to measure the forces driving and resisting landslide motion across a range of simulated scales, to guide development of numerical algorithms to simulate such motion, and to help in the framing of continuum models that can be applied simply to real world problems. The experimental results are to be disseminated as part of a new community initiative for establishing best practices for the sharing of laboratory data. Cutting-edge, open-source, 3d contact dynamics code, tailored to handling eroding granular flows and their impact on the environment, provides a valuable new cross-cutting resource. The project fosters new international collaboration with overseas engineers and geoscientists engaged in both experimental studies and in field assessments of granular flow hazards following recent typhoon and earthquake disasters. Mentoring is provided for two early career researchers and a graduate student in a project of unusual disciplinary breadth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broad goal of this project has been to advance our understanding of how channelized granular flows erode their boundaries. Erosion of soft beds leads to bulking of the flow and has a marked effect on the distance a granular flow will travel – with obvious implications for natural hazard assessment. Erosion of hard boundaries is an important component of landscape dynamics on the long-term, particularly in debris-flow channel incision, and has been little studied. Our research has made significant strides on both fronts.

Using a combination of theory, laboratory experiments and numerical modeling, we have shown that bulking of a granular flow as it flows over a granular bed needs no extra physics to explain the entrainment process. All that is required is to assume the flow velocity profile remains close to that at steady-state and to find an equation describing the flux of kinetic energy along the moving layer. Adding the latter to a depth-averaged treatment of fluxes of mass and momentum leads to a closed set of equations that describe a granular flow whose layer thickness thickens and thins at a predictable rate with only a modicum of model calibration.

This simple granular flow theory was tested in experiments using a linear flume and a rotating drum; the latter was augmented by testing under enhanced effective gravity using a 100g-ton geotechnical centrifuge. The experiments confirmed a host of model predictions, notably that grain size, wall friction, grain-grain friction (assuming a frictional fluid rheology), and key length scales in the problem combine in a non-trivial way during non-dimensionalization. This result contradicts previous work in the context of drum-driven flow that has simplistically assumed a Froude number control on the flow regime.

An adaptation of both these experimental and theoretical methods led to an advance in our understanding of erosion by sliding wear. Drum flow was used to simulate sustained channelized granular flow against an erodible rock substrate synthesized in the lab, and the flow regime was fixed using the new theory while varying the mean speed of grain sliding and pressure by tuning drum rotation rate and effective gravity (on the centrifuge) respectively. The outcome was that sliding wear takes place at a rate predicted by an modified form of Archard’s Equation and that rock hardness is the fundamental physical property that set its resistance to erosion. 

Related research was carried out using new discrete element methods to explore how well, and how badly, the assumption of a frictional fluid rheology expresses what in reality is a complex sequences of many-grain motions, and to help link better the laboratory experiments to the depth-averaged theory. These efforts helped to inform studies of large-scale landslide dynamics constrained by seismological observations.
